Belgia: 1590: March
15 March To M
r
Bodly
After our verie hartie Commendac
o
ns: The Queene Ma
tie
fynding it very strange, that to
such matters as have bin by yo
w
on her Ma
t
behalfe often propounded to the States g
n
al, she can [receyve]
no Resolution or direct answer, and thereby (as by other Courses, by them held towards her highnes)
she hath Cause to thinke her self unkindely and ingratefully [acquainted], for her gracious succours and
reliefe so liberally graunted unto them, in the tyme of their danger and necessitie, and Chargeably
contynued for their preservac
o
n, notw
th
standing a very chargeable warre fallen up
o
n her Ma
tie
and
her Realme, onely for adhearing to them: Hath thought it requisite that upon the receipt hereof
yo
w
addresse yo
r
self unto them, and after the delivery of yo
r
l
re
of Credence, (w
ch
yo
u
shall
receyve herewith) yo
u
declare unto the said States as from her Ma
tie
, how muche she resteth
offended w
th
their unkynde maner of dealyng w
th
her in the matters aforesaid, arguing a forgetfulnes
of the benefit they have receyved and doo receyve by her Ma
t
assistance, and of the danger she hath
drawen uppon her self and her estate by embracing their defence, wherein yo
u
may remember unto them
that for their Cause onely, even from the begyning of their troubles, her highnes first entred into
dowbtfull termes of Amitie w
th
the
Spanish King
, and sithence into open hostilitie for not
consenting to Condic
o
ns of peace offered to her in their respect, to her owne intollerable Charge
and burthen of her subject
: and that in her Ma
t
Course for their defence, how often she
hath bin voluntarilie drawen into great expence of her Threasure and of the blood of her
subject
, extraordinarily and beyond her promyse and Contract yelded, as namely of
Sluyce
,
at
Berghen
,
Ostend
and other places, all w
ch
by their Ingratitude, remayneth as throwen
into the sea, in that her Ma
tie
receyveth not from them somuche as thank
, or in their Actions
towards her, any significac
o
n of gratefull acceptance, of her inestimable goodnes and succours
geven unto them: but do rather showe a wilfull resoluc
o
n to Contend w
th
her Ma
tie
in
matters even of their own Contract and Covenant w
th
her highnes. When yo
u
shall therefore
have delivered thus muche (whiche yo
w
may amplifie in your best discretion) you shall descend
into the particularities of her Ma
t
request
folowing.
First you shall require them that the 12.
Companyes of
hundred
footmen sent over in liew of 600 horse
may be receyved and furthwith established by their publick Act in writing as alowed in
place of the said horse from the tyme of their entry into her Ma
t
pay, or otherwise you may
let them knowe that her Ma
tie
upon Notice of their Refusall, or accustomed delay of
answer shall have just Cause, presently to Revoke and dissolve the said Companyes.
Secondly yo
u
shall effectualy urge ther absolute Resoluc
o
ns to her Ma
t
other Demaunds
formerly made by your self, and abyde no longer delayes from the Councell of State upon
pretence of Insufficiencie of authoritie in them or in such of the states g
n
al as do reside at the
Haghe
. And by cause you advertise that the power and authoritie usually graunted to the
said Councell of State, is at this present so dimished, as they serve but onely for a shew
to geve apparance to maynteyne the Contract, and are in effect but Ciphres: Her Ma
tie
desireth to understand from them directly how far they have extended the aucthorite of the
said Councel, that if it shall appere they have not somuche as by the Contract is provided
& in sundry articles specially menc
o
ned the States may be required to Reforme the same according
fol.97v
Belgia: 1590: March:
to the Contract: for that her Ma
tie
expecteth that somuch shalbe Contynued to the said Councel at the least
as there by ought to be alowed: and therefore of in yo
r
Jugement upon viewe of the Last Instructions
to the said Councell, yo
u
shall fynde the power geven, not answerable to all the Articles of the
Contract: then shall yo
u
in her Ma
t
name require them to inlarge the same to the uttermost
Limit of the said Contract, w
ch
her Ma
t
supposeth they will not refuse, sith by virtue thereof
they are bounde thereunto.
Lastly for so much as we are informed that the C
o
missaries of Musters for the States doo
refuse to admitte such absences, as are allowed by her Ma
tie
in the last orders established here
and thereupon make stay to Close up their Muster Rolls: we thinke it meete that yo[u require
the said States to acqueynt her Ma[tie, w[th their liking or mislyking of the said orders, and w[th the reasons, that may induce them specially to mislike of the same,
that
they may be considered
of here, and receyve such needfull alterac
o
n (Yf there be cause) as by her Ma
tie
and us shalbe
thought fit: whose severall aunsweres to these and such other proposic
o
ns, as yo
u
have already
delivered unto them from her Ma
tie
, yo
u
shall retourne unto us
w
th
as convenient speede as may be.
And whereas the States g
n
al by their l
re
s written unto us of the last of Fe bruary
doo take exceptions to the apparaill sent over (by her Ma
t
orders geven) for the Clothing of
the soldyo
rs
in her pay, pretending the same to be hurtfull to their Townes and Provinces
and contrary to the Contract. You may for aunswere to their said l
re
s let them und
r
stand
that her Ma
tie
seeth no reason why she should not both apparaill and victuel the Companyes
of her owne succours, as not tyed by the Contract to maynteyne them w
th
paying mony only
but so they be waged and paid by her Ma
tie
for their defence (whether it be by geving them
victuel, apparell, mony, or otherwise) the Contract is not violated. Howbeyt to thend
the Townes be not prejudiced where her Ma
t
forces doo remayne, order shalbe taken
that (yf any parte of that apparaill or victuel shall be sold to any others then to the
soldiors of her Ma
t
succours) yt shalbe confiscable: for that her Ma
tie
meaneth not
that any person shold make any privat gayne under colo
r
of provision of apparaill
or victuel to be employed but onely uppon her owne soldiors. You shall moreover
signifie to the States or Councel of State that whereas they have used of Late (as we
are informed) to deliver bere and other victuel to the Companyes drawen owt of the
fower Garrisons under the Leading of
S
r
Frances Vere
, who notw
th
standing do
likewise receyve their weekly Imprest
in mony and victuel from her Ma
tie
for their
ordinary dyet
: They must have care not to deliver to the said Companyes more then
their due pay shall amounte unto, and to that ende yo
u
shall acqueynt the States or
Councell particularely, howmuch is delivered by her Ma
tie
to every soldio
r
in victuell and
mony weekly, w
ch
yo
u
may understand by
S
r
Thomas Sherleys
Deputies, that if
upon occasion they shall think fit at any tyme to make them any allowance of victuel
they geve knowledge thereof to the Th
re
r or his Deputies that it may be defalked
uppon
fol.98r
Belgia: 1590 March:
uppon their weekely lending
having the rest of their
full
pay in apparaill and Armes.
And to Conclude the States do also Complayne that at the
Bryell
all such shippes and
vessels, as do passe in and out the Ryver of Mose, nere to the fortes, are by the
Gouverno
r
(as they alleage) constrayned to cast ancker and to stay one Tyde to the hindranc
e
of their Trade: wherupon we having caused the Gouverno
r
remayning here, to shew
upon what respect
the same is don, dooth answer that it hath bin w
th
out his privitie
and allowance, at one tyme onely practised by a servant of the water bailiefe there, to
whome we have geven order to stay that Innovation, wherew
th
yo
u
may acqueynt the said
States in answer of their l
re
s, and may send for the serv
a
nte of the said waterbailiefe
or such other as is or hath bin aucthor of the said Innovac
o
n, to come unto yo
u
to the
Haghe
, and may signifye unto him our expresse Comaundem
t
that he forbeare the same
And so referring the well handeling and ordering hereof to yo
r
good discretion: we
byd yo
u
hartely farewell. From the Court at Greenewich the xv
th
of March 1589
Yo
r
verie Loving frends.
[John] Cant
